text:

educational resources for free. To make a donation or
view additional materials

from hundreds of MIT courses,
visit MIT OpenCourseWare at ocw.mit.edu.

AMY BANZAERT: Hi, everyone. Today we're going to be
doing trip prep and review. And so the first
part of trip prep--

this would work better if
I were actually projecting, wouldn't it? [CHUCKLES] So trip
prep and review.

And the first thing we're
going to do is presentation. So each team has 15
minutes to present, and then 5 to 10
minutes of questions.

And then we'll go through a
review of a few things that got missed or badly
presented previously,

and then going over trip
prep, and then there will be a little
bit of time for you guys to work in teams and
a few critical things.

I also need to talk to every
single person who's traveling, just one on one. It's a D-Lab requirement.

So we'll do that. Yeah, are there any
questions before we
start with the presentations?  OK, cool.

So AsoFenix, if you
guys want to go first, that would be awesome. GUEST SPEAKER: All
right, so we're AsoFenix.

I'm Carter. GUEST SPEAKER: I'm Buzz. GUEST SPEAKER: I'm Rosser. GUEST SPEAKER: Brianna. GUEST SPEAKER: And our
team mentor is Kem.

So AsoFenix is a
small Nicaraguan NGO. We're based in two areas--

El Roblar and Potreitos. And there are four products
that we're looking at right now.

One of them is the
OJ Sealer, which you guys might be aware of. The next would be the Millet
Thresher, the Washing Machine,

and the Biodigester. So I'm going to
hand it off to Buzz.

GUEST SPEAKER: So the OJ
sealer is a project that was a D-Lab project previously. And we're going to deliver it.

So I should be giving you the
group names, but I'm sorry. I don't have that right now.

But it was a previous-- it's not our project, so I don't
want to take credit for it.

But we are delivering it to
the community down there. And the purpose is to be able to
seal orange juice so that they

can sell it at a later date
during the harvest when oranges

are just so plentiful
that the cost really isn't worth sealing. So if they can bag the juice
and then sell it later,

they'll be able to make
money from their harvest. So how it works is you have--

it's kind of like the
sealers we use in the lab. And you bring down
this lever here,

and then you can latch it. There's a latch that
secures it in place, and that's a safety
feature, and also ensures

a good connection between
the metal and the plastic

so that you get a good seal
and also you can't just jolt it or lift
it up accidentally

and then you end up with a
mess and possibly an injury. So there's a latch.

There's a switch that
you press and then it heats for 10 seconds. You can adjust that time.

We'll have to, I guess,
optimize that time. It's set to 10 seconds now. From what I understand,
that's arbitrary.

So we might adjust that time. And there's an
LED that lights up while the rod is heating so that
the user knows that it is hot

and not to undo the
latch and open the rod. So this project-- and
10 seconds of heating,

and the metal that's used
heats up very quickly and also cools off very quickly.

So after that 10
seconds is over, you allow, like, 5
seconds of cooling, and then you can open
the lever safely.

So we're going to go down and
implement the project and some of the instructions
that we'll have to give

and how to handle the
plastic waste that they have, because they're most likely
not accustomed to having

the sheets of plastic and what
to make sure they understand the consequences of
littering in the environment,

and then also explain
the operations.

Oh, GUEST SPEAKER: You're next. GUEST SPEAKER: So
when we were first getting the groups in
the projects and stuff,

there was mention
of a feed chopper. Well after talking
with AsoFenix, we can tell they're
actually interested in is

it a different part
of harvest processing is threshing their millet crop. And that means is taking all
the little seeds are within,

they call them florets-- little stalks on the big one--
and removing all the seeds from it and separating the stuff you
can eat from stuff you can't.

So these are a couple
different designs that have been built
by various groups.

They're both-- you can't see
the actual mechanism that's

doing the threshing
in either of them, but it's basically they've
got little spikes on.

I think this one has two
drums inside each other with little spikes that are
just knocking the seeds out.

And this one they've taken
the tire off the wheel, and they're using all
the spokes sticking out

of the frame of the
wheel to pick it off. Since we only found out what
the project was very recently,

we haven't done much thinking
about our own designs with this stuff.

We're wondering if these
are kind of capacity though. So mainly on the trip we're
going to be getting information

about the process,
since it's not something we're familiar
with what you need to do to thresh the millet.

Their harvest is 4,000 pounds. So we need to know how much
that actually is so you

an idea of how much we need
to be threshing at the time. And then there are
different varieties.

We need to know
what variety they're using, which will
help determine what the appropriate method
of threshing it is.

How long they need to do it--
and they're currently doing it by hand-- and how efficient is this?

There was discussion
about moving the machine between different communities. And so whether the
different communities

are harvesting at
the same time or not is going to affect how
fast it needs to work, because if everyone's
harvesting at the same time,

that's more people that need
to get their harvest done within a smaller amount of time.

But if somebody a few miles
away is lower elevation and has the harvest
slightly earlier,
that gives us more time spread.  So the preliminary specs--

they're currently taking four
days to thresh the harvest. We could get that
down to eight hours. All of these, I'm not going to
go through and read them all

because they're mostly very
arbitrary at this point. And for this project,
it's going to be

a lot of information gathering.  GUEST SPEAKER: OK, so the next
project we wanted to look at

was a washing machine. Interestingly enough, we were
kind of so gung-ho for this that we kind of leapt through
and did the most planning.

And it turns out that
AsoFenix said, no, we'd rather have focus on this. So, you know, that's part
of the planning process.

But in any case-- oh, shoot. Did the chart not come through? Anyway. So some key things
we want to keep

in mind for the washing machine
are the preservation of water. There might not be that much
water to use in this community.

AsoFenix really also wants
to utilize the gray water to do something useful,
rather than just dumping it.

We also have a couple
of different variables to consider. So D-Lab has done a lot of
work with washing machines

in the past. This is one of the designs
they've come up with. Benji is not here right now,
but he also showed us one

that he did for
D-Lab design that was a similar design like this.

So we kind of took
this and ran with it. Yes, so this is
basically the same idea,

except using direct
drive from a bicycle that can be detached and then
still used as a bicycle, instead of a bicycle
that's gutted for parts

and mounted directly
to the thing. The key variable we'd
like to test here is whether to do
side- or top-loading.

That kind of depends
how efficient and easy it is to load. We'd also like to alter and
play with the inner drum design.

Should we make it out of rope? Should we make it
out of chicken wire? We were thinking for a while
of doing nylon bags that

would be put in place. So that would spin and
be their own rotors. And then also the draining
methods, though again,

we can preserve as much
gray water as we can. Sorry, I had a spec sheet,
and apparently my open Office

format kind of ate it. But they're all intuitive. GUEST SPEAKER: And
then the product

that AsoFenix wanted us to
focus on was the biodigester. So what this is
is basically they

wanted us to find a way
to efficiently mix up the slew based off their
current concrete and plastic bag

method. So here are spec sheets. Basically, you want it
to be hand-powered or bicycle-powered.

The main requirement being
there's no electricity needed. We need something that
stays in the same scale

that they already have,
4 to 10 cubic meters. And then after
one use, they want

to produce about 1
cubic meter of biogas and take about two or
three hours to complete.

Those are the main specs that
they wanted us to achieve. Upon further discussions
with AsoFenix,

they showed us that this
is their current design, and they wanted us
to actually not focus on a method of making the
slew, but actually finding

a way or a method to
determine overflow, improve their current
process, and find a way

to gauge how much biogas their
producing at any given time. So right now what's
happening is you can see the plastic
bags in the background,

and the biogas is delivered
through this tube from right to left. And as there's an overflow, it
goes down this pipe and bubbles

in the water. So if any user were to see
bubbles throughout the water, they would know that there's
being overflow usage.

That being said, you don't
know how much is in the tubes until it's too much.

This can only determine whether
it's overflowing or not, and you can only tell
that if you're there

and see the bubbles. So if you're asleep
and it starts bubbling, you won't know
this is happening.

And so they want to
find a new method to determine how much
biogas is being produced.

So we changed the whole project
in regards to this, instead of a mixer, and started looking
at the manometer pressure gauge

system of how to determine
how much gas is there. So we're thinking about throwing
basically just a rubber tube,

having a fixed diameter
circular objects, such as a soda can, plastic
bottle, so we have a fixed

diameter that's common there. And we'd wrap the
plastic tubing around it

and fill it up with water. And we'd measure, make sure
the water levels are even. And then we would
release the valve,

so we can see the pressure
difference between the water. And that head difference is how
much pressure there is inside.

And then we'll have markings
saying, if it's this much head difference, then there
will be blank amount

of pressure, which means
0.6 cubic meters of biogas.

And then every day
they can check out how much biogas there is because
of the pressure difference.

And then once they hit a
certain head loss difference, then they will know they're
reaching their overflow

capacity. This will help them
determine how much they have and how much they can use.

So let's say if they wanted to
use some and they weren't full, they wouldn't want to try to use
0.25 cubic meters if they only
have 0.1. So this is the biodigester. And some key activities--

basically, just a quick
summary of our projects. The OJ sealer--

GUEST SPEAKER: Yeah,
so this outlines what each project is
going to accomplish

while we're down there. So we're going to
deliver the OJ sealer, explain its uses and
benefits to the community.

And then for most of the
other ones, they're mostly-- GUEST SPEAKER: Right, we can't
observe the shelling process

for the millet or
inquire into it if it's not an appropriate
time to observe it.

And gather more information. GUEST SPEAKER: For
the washing machine, we'll determine which
features will be useful.

We'll look at how they
wash their clothes now and just how we can optimize
that with our machine.

GUEST SPEAKER: For
the biodigester, we want to go there, see
their current method,

and see how we can
implement our process and see if we can help teach
them our preliminary concept

and get feedback from them. GUEST SPEAKER: And overall,
just objectives for our trip.

We also want to explore a
typical Nicaraguan hardware store to see if we
were to give them

a design for a project,
what materials they have available at hand,
and then also develop

the relationships with
the community partners down there so we
can continue working as a D-Lab program
with them, and then

just take all necessary
measurements that might be helpful to relate
to each individual project.

GUEST SPEAKER: And
finally, we'd like to give acknowledgments
to Amy, Cami, Ken, D-Lab,
MIT, and AsoFenix. Any questions?

[APPLAUSE]  AMY BANZAERT: I want to
give other people a chance

to ask questions, but I have
a few questions and comments. I'm sorry, guys.

So one is, did you get
the sealer working? Were you able to connect
it to a power supply?

GUEST SPEAKER: We haven't. AMY BANZAERT: OK,
so you should do that before you leave to
make sure it's still working.

Preferably real soon,
so if it's not working you can troubleshoot it. And you might also want to
deal into that plastic box

so you can make the
timing adjustment. I know that the timer
was set for 10 seconds

because with the plastic bags
that this group was using, that got them
consistent good sealing,

even with orange juice flopped
over in the sealing zone.

But we don't know what bags
will be used by AsoFenix, so that's why you want
to be able to adjust it.

But yeah, it's pretty
critical that you don't bring it and then be
like, oh, it doesn't work. It'd be good to know why
it doesn't work, at least.

So it'd be good to
know before you leave. For the millet
thresher, I don't if you

were referred Donna Cohn
at Hampshire College, but she's been working on
pearl millet threshing a lot.

And so she might
be a good resource, both in terms of
ideas as well as I

grow she's been trying to
grow pearl millet out there. And so if you do end up
working on this project,

one of your challenges
will be not having access to the thing you're
actually trying to work on, because you can't bring
it back from Nicaragua

without going through the
US agricultural stuff. And that's going to take longer
than the rest of the semester,

probably, to get through. So finding out from her if
she is, in fact, growing it, if she does have
a supply, would be

pretty useful to know if the
project is going to be viable.

And then I liked your
list of universal things. I do have some lists
of products available,

in general, Nicaraguan hardware
stores that I can send you, too.

But I'd definitely visit one
and get a sense yourself. I would also encourage you
to identify other projects

that they might be interested
in, either for this year or for future years. It's nice to just
have an ongoing list.

successfully as opposed to not. And then also just documenting
as much as possible

about their particular
millet because there are a lot of different varieties. And so if they don't work with
Pearl millet but something

else, or Donna has a different
version of Pearl millet, it'd be good to know
what the differences are. GUEST SPEAKER: One
thing that we want

to do with all the products
is see their current process and identify key aspects of what
is it they're actually doing
and how to recognize that. But yeah. AMY BANZAERT: Cool.

And then you guys were
thinking about trying to build the biodigester sensor, right?

So do you have your materials
list for that prepared and you know what you're
either bringing from here or what they can get there?

GUEST SPEAKER: Mm-hmm. AMY BANZAERT: OK. Awesome. Thanks. GUEST SPEAKER: Any
other questions?
[APPLAUSE]
GUEST SPEAKER: So hi, everyone. We are a Grupo Fenix. My name is Jessica. GUEST SPEAKER: Liz. GUEST SPEAKER: Vivan. GUEST SPEAKER: Sid.

GUEST SPEAKER: Juan. GUEST SPEAKER: And Kurt
is here in spirit with us all the way from Costa Rica. He's doing some
fieldwork beforehand.

[CHUCKLES] No he's not. So in our presentation
today, we decided that part of our project,
which we'll learn about,

is charcoal cookers. And we're going to have
to teach the community and teach them how
to work with it.

So we're going to be presenting
in front of this community. And we're not going to have the
PowerPoint or anything to help us with the presentation.

So we tried to make
this a little demo and see how we can do
that to this crowd. So we're not going to
speak in Spanish today,

but we are going to try to let
go of PowerPoint presentations today. So a little bit about our trip.

So in today's
presentation, I'll tell you a little bit about
our trip, and we'll walk you through each of our
projects, our final sketches

that we have, what we're
working on right now, and what are some final
calculations that we want to do before we
head out there next week.

And I'll just start with some
little bit of background. So we'll be visiting Ocotal,
which is, like, 20 minutes--

no, we'll be visiting Grupo
Fenix, which is, like, 20 minutes outside of Ocotal,
which is north of Managua,

which is Nicaragua's capital. And we're going to
be basically working with a group of women called
the Solar Women of Totogalpa.

And they are, again, a
group of around 20, 25 women that are interested in
solar-- solar design.

They've designed their
own solar cooker. And you know a little bit about
that background information.

In our trip, we're going
to try to evaluate. Our main objectives are to
evaluate the existing products and brainstorm ways
to improve, so working

with what they have on site. We've already sent them
with the materials list of what they should
prepare for us, stuff to do the charcoal burns,
and stuff to just see what they

have on site to work with them. And finally, while
we're there, we'll show them what we have
in mind, and we'll

try to meet in the middle
from what they want and what we have
in mind and make that happen when we come back.

So first we'll start with
the charcoal project. GUEST SPEAKER: So there's
actually two parts to the charcoal project.

The first is that
we're going to be doing a charcoal burn with them. They've actually been taught
how to do this before. They still have the
materials from last time.

So mostly, we're just going
to refresh their memories. So I think a lot of what we're
going to do in the teaching is, instead of doing
everything ourselves,

we're mostly going to stand
back and watch what they already know how to do,
and then be like, oh, it might work a little bit
better if you do it this way.

And then show them maybe
a little improvement that they can do. So it's kind of just making
sure that what they're doing now is correct and trying to
improve it a little bit.

But then the other
thing we're doing is working with the
charcoal stoves. If you remember when you saw
projects from previous D-Labs,

there was this sheet metal
stove that was all one piece, and it was cut up,
and then folded into this hexagonal shape
with a slightly open-up top.

So we're going to be trying
to either improve that stove or come up with a new one,
depending on their needs, when we go there.

So we had some ideas
for improving that one. A basic one was just
to add insulation.

So if you add clay around the
base of it, kind of like these stoves that we
saw the other day, then that might help
the insulation a lot.

And we talked to Grupo
Fenix, and they actually have a man in the
town who has a kiln. And they said we can use
it as long as we tell them

when we want to use it. So we're planning on
taking advantage of that and just actually trying
that when we're there,

like putting whatever clay
materials that they have easily available and baking
it, and then seeing if that improves how quickly
you can cook with it.

We're also going to try some
other things like adding-- using chicken wire or some
other easily available material

on top of that so that they
can have not really a grill, but just a surface on top
of the stove on which they

can put things so it's more
adjustable for sizes of pants. We also might need
to improve airflow, but it kind of
depends on which pans

they're using it
with because as long as their pans aren't
perfectly fitting, then it has enough airflow.

But if we need more,
we can either-- if we're using the clay, we
can lift it up a little bit

but have some
holes underneath so that it can come up
from beneath and then the air can keep the fire going
or keep the charcoal burning.

Or we could just make the
design a little bit looser, because it's held together
right now by a string

around the outside of the top. And if you loosen that
string a little bit, it actually might open
up holes a little bit

in the design to let
more air flow through. But we also could
design a new stove.

GUEST SPEAKER: Well,
yeah, so we're also looking at the design
that could be a new stove. From what we've seen
that what actually works

is the stove that we had last
time, the big cased stove, the-- oh, I can't believe
I forgot the name.

But yeah, the one
we saw last time that was going to be full of
clay that close to the middle. And handles, we're
thinking of, because we

have a kiln over
there, we can just complete the design of
the stove with the women. Some of the improvements
we were thinking about

were adding handles that
would be easy to carry, out of a different material. Adding a door we'd also add
to increase the airflow.

And also adding a tray so
you can put the charcoal in and out as much as
you out of the stove.

So while we're there, we're also
going to look with the women

and what is that they actually
cook, the heat they need, where it is that they cook--
so if it needs more shelter

or less shelter from the wind-- how much time do
they actually have to produce or to make the
charcoal, how much time do

they have, and how easy it is to
actually place the stoves where they are living--

so if it's really easy to
carry up and put down or if they need to move it
a kilometer every day.

Also cooking time and
they have available sizes

and shapes that we can have. GUEST SPEAKER: OK, yeah,
so next thing we worked on
is the solar cooker project.

Now, basically we
approached it three ways. We talked about the existing
research that was already done.

We looked into what
they have currently. We looked into the
product specifications. And we looked into the
question that we had for them.

As far as the
literature goes, we looked into what types
of solar cooker designs

predominantly exist right now. And there are basically
three types of designs. You have curved concentrators,
which are basically,

like, you have your
cooker here, and you have some kind of parabolic
mirror, which reflects sunlight into the cooker.

And they're curved concentrators
because the parabola is the curve. The second type is
a heat box, which

is basically just a box which
uses the greenhouse effect. So you have the sunlight
hitting the box and then the box

retaining a lot of heat. And then the third type is
your panel solar cooker,

which is basically like a box
with a hinged mirror on it, where you have sunlight
hitting the mirror

and then getting
reflected on to the box. So those are the three types
that predominantly exist.

When we looked into what they
have currently with them there, they basically use a
hybrid between the heat box

heater and the panel
heater, where some designs do have our panels
but then they also

use reflective surfaces
inside to keep it warm.

GUEST SPEAKER: So a group
from Columbia University has been working with the
Solar Women of Totogalpa

to develop what they
currently have now. And it's, as Sid said,
this box solar cooker.

The one thing we
really, really want to focus on when we get there
is figuring out why it's so expensive to manufacture.

The Women really
pride themselves in being able to make
this cooker on their own.

So we want to see how we can
work with them, what they like about the cooker, and
specifically what materials

make it so expensive to make. So we came up with
a new final design

that we might want
to improve upon. And it's kind of the same, but
I think to really move forward

with this we really need to
figure out the materials that are available to us. And stuff like that.

So want to talk about the specs? GUEST SPEAKER: Yeah. I just wanted to really
gear over real quick. So the designs,
basically we wanted

to do two different
types of designs. One was where we were
trying to improve what they have
currently, and one

was we wanted to
design something new. And so basically we
came up with two things.

So this is an improvement, and
we might pass it around later. But this is an improvement--

I think what we think
is an improvement-- on their current design. We think it might
reduce material costs and improve efficiency.

This design is kind
of like a mixture between the curved
concentrator and the heat box.

Essentially, this is trying
to make a pressure cooker. We weren't sure if
there's a need for that.

So that's actually
one of our questions. We're wondering how
much food they actually cook using pressure cookers. But we didn't see any literature
about them using anything

like that currently,
and we were wondering if it was possibly of any use. So those are the basic
two designs we worked on.

And then, Vivan, you can
talk about the project specs. GUEST SPEAKER: Yeah. So some of our
specs are it needs to definitely retain heat.

So we'll consider different
types of insulation. It has to be able to reach
high temperatures whether they

need to be cooking
different kinds of meat or just boiling water. It also has to be able to
withstand different weather

conditions. If it's going to be
sitting outside-- because it is a solar cooker-- the climate in Nicaragua
is kind of humid,

and it does rain a lot. So that's really important. It needs to be affordable, which
we've already mentioned before,

and easy to manufacture, or
fairly easy to manufacture. GUEST SPEAKER: Yeah, we actually
came up with a bunch of them.

But these were what we thought
were the most important. Another thing that
could play a role is how aesthetically
pleasing it is,

because we did come
across literature where they refused to use
certain cookers because they didn't like the way
that they looked.

So that's a very
important part also, which we're trying to work on. Yeah, that's pretty much what
we're working on right now.

GUEST SPEAKER: Right. And so last but not least is
the solar cell phone charger. And I'll be speaking on behalf
of me and Kurt for this one.

So two key findings that we
had in our literature research were just a comment
that solar is

the most flexible and
efficient of off-grid chargers. And we were like,
yay, thumbs up. And they gave the rule of
thumb that about 60 minutes

of charging would
mean 10 minutes of talking on the phone. Now, the specifications of what
kind of panels you're using

and whatever you're not,
all that can be optimized. So that led us to one of
our design considerations,

which is in the schematic--
basically, a communal charger, so just having instead
of one small solar panel,

enough to charge one
cell phone at a time, having a big communal
charging station. But of course, that
requires the field work

of being there for
this week and realizing whether these people can
actually work together, whether there's going
to be a risk of having

your charger stolen or having
your cell phone battery stolen while it's being charged,
or whether you can have

some kind of a system where you
leave something that's yours and that doesn't get stolen
while you take the battery.

So seeing how that works,
what the different kinds of batteries that they're
using in their cell phones are.

And so one idea that
also stemmed from that is having a port that's
adaptable to different kinds

of cell phone chargers, because
if they change their cell phone, then you're not going to
throw away the whole charging station.

So that's some of the
ideas that came from that. And another thing we
were thinking about was the design
consideration that they're

going to be using their
cell phones on the fields. A lot of times
they'll leave home, they'll go work on
the field, they'll

go look for food,
whatever it is, and they'll have their cell
phones on them for a long time.

So if they ever have it with
them for longer than needed,

they won't be able to come
home and just charge it or plug in their charger that
they have in their pocket into a wall outlet, right?

Unrealistic. So one thing we thought is
some kind of mobile charger. One technology that is a little
advanced I think for our skills

right now is it's a
layer of solar cells that's integrated below the
LCD screens of the iPhones.

But we thought that
something to that effect, where the women could
